misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `studentScores` array, the corresponding student names in `studentNames` will still match up by index (i.e., the “top score ends up at the last index, so the top name is also at the last index”).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` reorders only the `studentScores` array. It has no knowledge of (and does not adjust) the separate `studentNames` array. Parallel arrays only remain aligned if you perform the same swaps/reordering to both arrays, or if you sort a combined structure (e.g., objects/pairs) rather than sorting one array alone. After sorting scores, the index of the maximum score is no longer guaranteed to be the index of the same student’s name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints a name that may not belong to the highest score (names and scores can become mismatched).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Remain Synchronized After Sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the `studentScores` array in ascending order, the corresponding student names in the `studentNames` array will automatically stay paired with their original scores. Since they sort scores and then grab the name at the same index, they expect this to give them the correct student-score pair.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that `Arrays.sort()` operates on a single array in isolation. When you sort one array, it has no effect on parallel arrays. The indices that once connected names to scores are now broken. After sorting scores, `studentNames[numberOfStudents - 1]` points to whatever name was originally last, not the name of the student with the highest score. In this example, sorting scores [85, 92, 78] to [78, 85, 92] leaves names as [Alice, Bob, Charlie], so the code retrieves Charlie (92) instead of Bob (92).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program prints the wrong student name paired with the correct highest score, or prints the wrong name-score pair entirely.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because they built the arrays in parallel (reading names and scores into corresponding indices), the indices will forever maintain that coupling even after one array is modified. They think sorting is a 'labeling' operation that somehow preserves the logical pairing.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student conflates the order of data entry with invariant index alignment. In reality, sorting rearranges only the array being sorted. Index `i` in `studentScores` no longer refers to the same student as index `i` in `studentNames` after the sort. The parallel array pattern requires maintaining this coupling manually (e.g., by swapping both arrays together or using a custom comparator with an auxiliary index array), which the student did not do.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: mismatched name-score pairs in the final result.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since names and scores were entered together into matching index positions, the computer recognizes them as linked pairs. Therefore, sorting the 'scores' array will automatically rearrange the 'names' array to maintain those pairs, or the index that now holds the highest score will still correctly correspond to the same person in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The relationship between 'studentNames[i]' and 'studentScores[i]' is a convention the programmer created, not a structural link recognized by the JVM. Using 'Arrays.sort()' on one array rearranges its elements without affecting the other, effectively 'decoupling' the scores from the names.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if you sort the scores array, the corresponding student names will still “line up” by index (i.e., the name at the last index will automatically be the student who got the highest score).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `studentNames` and `studentScores` are two independent arrays. `Arrays.sort(studentScores)` only reorders the integers inside `studentScores`. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder `studentNames` to match. Parallel arrays only stay aligned if your code explicitly swaps/moves elements in both arrays in the same way (or if you use a single combined data structure like an object and sort those objects).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name can be unrelated to the highest score (it will just print the *last-entered* name paired with the *highest* score after sorting).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the `studentScores` array using `Arrays.sort()`, the `studentNames` array will automatically rearrange itself to maintain the pairing between each student's name and their score. They think the sort operation somehow knows about and adjusts both arrays together.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java's `Arrays.sort()` method operates only on the array it is called on—it modifies only `studentScores`. The `studentNames` array remains completely untouched and stays in its original input order. Parallel arrays are independent data structures; there is no automatic mechanism that keeps them synchronized when one is modified. Once the scores are sorted, the correspondence between names and scores at the same index is broken. For example, if the input is names=[Alice, Bob, Charlie] and scores=[85, 92, 78], after sorting only the scores, we have scores=[78, 85, 92] but names=[Alice, Bob, Charlie]. The highest score (92) is now at index 2, but index 2 still contains 'Charlie' (not 'Bob'), so the output will be incorrect.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are treated as 'parallel' (where the index i in both arrays refers to the same entity), performing a sorting operation on one array will automatically reorder the elements of the other array to preserve the conceptual link between them.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The relationship between 'studentNames[0]' and 'studentScores[0]' exists only because of the order in which the programmer populated them. The 'Arrays.sort()' method only has access to the specific array passed as an argument; it has no knowledge of, or mechanism to update, other variables or arrays that the programmer conceptually associates with that data.
